Idiom (Quenya): Cenë i cala ve rámar úvë
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause, comparative structure using ve (‘as, like’)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To understand something deeply or clearly (‘see the light’)
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old metaphor from Valinorean teachings — light equates with truth and comprehension
First Example Sentence: Cenë i cala ve rámar úvë an i hlaruva órenyallo.
Second Example Sentence: Úvë i lómë, cenë i cala ve rámar úvë.
Third Example Sentence: Ceninyë i cala ve rámar úvë tenna lómë caluva.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase, active voice with locative phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To listen for subtle hints or read between the lines
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from poetic imagery of hearing wings in the night — symbolizes sensitivity
First Example Sentence: Hlarinyë i rámar mi lómë ar istan i auta.
Second Example Sentence: I nís hlarë i rámar mi lómë ar quetë mahtala.
Third Example Sentence: Hlarë i rámar mi lómë yassen quén úvë quetë.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase, imperative mood (to pass into darkness)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To perish, disappear, or be forgotten
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Ancient expression from the downfall of Beleriand — denotes death or fading memory
First Example Sentence: I nér auta mi lómë ar úvë entuva.
Second Example Sentence: Auta mi lómë, ar nai cala entuluva.
Third Example Sentence: I quén quentë ‘auta mi lómë’ ve hosta sinomë.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative verb phrase in present tense
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be stubborn or refuse advice
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To ignore what one is told
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: A common domestic idiom — reflects Quenya emphasis on listening as virtue
First Example Sentence: I nér úvë hlarë náva ar úvë carë mára.
Second Example Sentence: Vendë nánë quen úvë hlarë náva ar qualë.
Third Example Sentence: Áva ná quen úvë hlarë náva, melindo.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with locative case (study in a pattern)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To read between the lines or perceive hidden patterns
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To analyze deeply or interpret meaning
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from Elvish scholarly traditions — ‘cilmë’ means pattern, design
First Example Sentence: Cendinyë mi cilmë i parma sina.
Second Example Sentence: Hlarin i nér cenda mi cilmë ar ista anwa.
Third Example Sentence: Cenda mi cilmë i hesto úvë hlarë.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Future tense clause with active participle
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To foresee danger or trouble approaching
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Linked to prophetic imagery from Eldar seers who ‘hear the nights falling’
First Example Sentence: Hlaruva i lómi caita ar auta númenna.
Second Example Sentence: I quén hlaruva i lómi caita úvë mára.
Third Example Sentence: Hlaruva i lómi caita ve aranya ná istan.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with subjunctive mood (if the sun does not shine)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To expect the worst or be pessimistic
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects Valinorean humor — assuming gloom despite light
First Example Sentence: Hlarë i anor úvë caluva, úvë cenë nai cala entuluva.
Second Example Sentence: I nér hlarë i anor úvë caluva ar laita núra.
Third Example Sentence: Áva hlarë i anor úvë caluva, melindo.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Metaphoric noun phrase (weak bird among wings)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To be out of place or inferior in a group
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To feel like one does not belong
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: A proverb among Noldor artisans — humility through imagery of weak wings
First Example Sentence: Nánë úmëa aiwë mi rámar mi osto Eldaron.
Second Example Sentence: Vendë quentë, ‘úmëa aiwë mi rámar’, ar naitalë.
Third Example Sentence: Áva cenë ni ve úmëa aiwë mi rámar.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with object (to praise the nights)
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To find beauty in sorrow or to romanticize sadness
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Symbolic of the Eldar artistic melancholy after the exile to Middle-earth
First Example Sentence: I vendë laita lómi mi lindalë.
Second Example Sentence: Quén laita lómi ar hlaruva i rámar.
Third Example Sentence: Nánë Elda quén laita lómi tenna cala entuluva.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Compound subjunctive phrase with poetic inversion
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To hope for good fortune in dark times
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old Valinorean blessing — light as hope amid night
First Example Sentence: Nai calima aiwë hlaruva lómi mi órenya.
Second Example Sentence: Nai calima aiwë hlaruva lómi tenna lómë auta.
Third Example Sentence: Ceninyë nai calima aiwë hlaruva lómi mi yávië.
